column1: ap 00:00|twelve|"But the opportunity did not present itself
column2: and they pulled into Dawson one dreary afternoon with the great fight still to come. Here were many men
column4: and Buck found them all at work. It seemed the ordained order of things that dogs should work. All day they swung up and down the main street in long teams
column5: and in the night their jingling bells still went by. They hauled cabin logs and firewood
column7: and did all manner of work that horses did in the Santa Clara Valley. Here and there Buck met Southland dogs
column8: but in the main they were the wild wolf husky breed. Every night
column14: in which it was Buck’s delight to join."|"The Call of the Wild"|"Jack London"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"It was beautiful spring weather
column2: but neither dogs nor humans were aware of it. Each day the sun rose earlier and set later. It was dawn by three in the morning
column3: and twilight lingered till nine at night. The whole long day was a blaze of sunshine. The ghostly winter silence had given way to the great spring murmur of awakening life. The murmur arose from all the land
column4: fraught with the joy of living. It came from the things that lived and moved again
column5: things which had been as dead and which had not moved during the long months of frost. The sap was rising in the pines. The willows and aspens were bursting out in young buds. Shrubs and vines were putting on fresh garbs of green. Crickets sang in the nights
column6: and in the days all manner of creeping
column7: crawling things rustled forth into the sun. Partridges and woodpeckers were booming and knocking in the forest. Squirrels were chattering
column9: and overhead honked the wild-fowl driving up from the south in cunning wedges that split the air."|"The Call of the Wild"|"Jack London"

column1: 21:00|"nine at night"|"It was beautiful spring weather

column2: and back and forth they twisted through the uncharted vastness
column3: where no men were and yet where men had been if the Lost Cabin were true. They went across divides in summer blizzards
column4: shivered under the midnight sun on naked mountains between the timber line and the eternal snows
column5: dropped into summer valleys amid swarming gnats and flies
column6: and in the shadows of glaciers picked strawberries and flowers as ripe and fair as any the Southland could boast. In the fall of the year they penetrated a weird lake country
column9: but where then there was no life nor sign of life – only the blowing of chill winds
column10: the forming of ice in sheltered places
column11: and the melancholy rippling of waves on lonely beaches."|"The Call of the Wild"|"Jack London"

column1: 02:30|vigils|"For two days and nights Buck never left camp
column2: never let Thornton out of his sight. He followed him about his work
column4: saw him into his blankets at night and out of them in the morning. But after two days the call in the forest began to sound more imperiously than ever. Buck’s restlessness came back on him
column5: and he was haunted by recollections of the wild brother
column6: and of the smiling land beyond the divide and the run side by side through the wide forest stretches. Once again he took to wandering in the woods
column7: but the wild brother came no more; and though he listened through long vigils
column8: the mournful howl was never raised."|"The Call of the Wild"|"Jack London"
